node.title: Going Out and Worried About Covid Safety? Thereâ€™s a Calculator for That.
node.description: Age + vaccination status + number of guests + ZIP code + activity = Should I even leave the house?
node.content: ["Before David Lee gathered with his parents for Christmas, he and his family took Covid-19 precautions. They isolated themselves a few days before meeting. His parents, who are more vulnerable because of their age, got the vaccine booster shot, as did Mr. Lee, 43, a photo editor who lives in Toronto. His children, ages 8 and 10, got their first vaccine shot. And they all took rapid tests leading up to the holiday. ", "\u201cWith all the different things added together, it felt like a relatively safe gamble to gather for the holidays,\u201d he said.", "Still, he wanted to be extra sure.", "So a week before Christmas he used a Covid risk calculator he found on the internet. This one was created by Canada\u2019s National Institute on Ageing, and it asked him questions such as how many people would be at the gathering, how old everyone is and whether everyone had been fully vaccinated.", "He plugged in additional information about where they would be meeting (indoors or outdoors) and what they would be doing (talking, eating, singing, hugging). The calculator incorporated information about Covid rates and community spread in Toronto, where the gathering would take place, and then assessed his risk of being exposed to Covid-19 at the event.", "He was relieved the answer was low. \u201cIf there was a red flag, it would have at least given us pause,\u201d he said. \u201cThis tool is about understanding the risk, about having a third party arbiter saying, \u2018Maybe this isn\u2019t a good idea.\u2019\u201d", "Covid risk assessment calculators are a recent weapon in people\u2019s quest to go about their normal lives while staying safe. Universities, governments and nonprofits have created different versions to help people assess their particular situations.", "Each calculator is created differently. The one Mr. Lee used was created by a process named the Delphi Method, in which a group of 20 experts including infectious disease specialists and epidemiologists rated risky behavior \u2014 eating inside, for example \u2014 on a scale of 0 to 10. ", "Their responses were aggregated to assign a score to each behavior a user reports (perhaps hugging an unvaccinated person). The team revises the calculator every three months as they get new information about what constitutes risky behavior and different behaviors that can add to or mitigate risk (they recently added rapid testing, for example).", "Calculators vary slightly. Some assess your risk of contracting Covid at a particular gathering. Other calculators measure the likelihood of someone arriving with the virus to your event (rather than your chance of catching it) or how likely you are to get Covid in an indoor site like a grocery store or hair salon. Users like them because they provide an objective way to check or justify their decisions.", "\u201cEvery scenario is different,\u201d said Dr. Samir Sinha, the director of geriatrics at the Sinai Health System and University Health Network in Toronto, who helped created the tool Mr. Lee used. \u201cIt\u2019s like being about to call Dr. Fauci and say, \u2018You know, Tony, I am going to this event, this is the situation, what do you think?\u2019\u201d", "The calculators can ease anxiety in different ways. Kelly Guillemette, 52, a retiree who lives outside of Toronto, found out that events she thought were high risk actually weren\u2019t. \u201cThe app made me say, \u2018Maybe I am causing myself excess anxiety in my own head?\u2019\u201d she said. \u201cI was having a really, really hard time trusting the outside world.\u201d", "Some people have even incorporated these calculators into their day-to-day lives.", "\u201cI am using it for every decision I have to make when I leave the house,\u201d said Alison Bergstom, 44, who lives in Cambridge, Mass., and is getting a master\u2019s degree in data science and analytics. She uses a calculator created by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology that assesses the risk of being with other people inside.", "Before Thanksgiving, she used a calculator to assess her risk in going to Costco. \u201cTo consider how big the store is, how many people will be there, are people going to be wearing masks, are people going to be eating samples,\u201d she said. \u201cI changed my entire schedule around when it said the risk was high. I went Monday morning as soon as it opened so it was less busy and I could go in and out.\u201d", "She also crunched numbers before going to a hair appointment. \u201cThe app asked how many people would be there and what they would be doing. I realized people would be talking loudly because the hair dryers would be on,\u201d she said. \u201cIt showed the risk was quite significant so I decided not to do it.\u201d", "(These calculators encourage you to make your most educated guess when filling in the data. For example, if you know a bar checks for vaccine cards at the door you can say with certainty everyone inside is vaccinated. If a bar doesn\u2019t check for vaccine cards, you can infer the data from local vaccination rates.)", "Christina Hendriks, 39, who is pursuing a master\u2019s degree in public health and lives in Waynesville, N.C., uses an app that was developed by a team at the University of Oxford every morning. \u201cIt\u2019s become part of my routine,\u201d she said. \u201cI run the calculator if we have to go to a doctor\u2019s appointment, go shopping or do in-person banking.\u201d", "She said that rather than making her anxious, the calculator empowers her to make informed decisions. When transmission rates are low, she can see the data showing she can resume normal activities with reasonable precautions. When transmission rates are high, she scales back her activities. ", "\u201cWith the data you don\u2019t feel as trapped or as hopeless,\u201d she said. \u201cThere are periods where it shows I need to bunker down for a while, but there are also periods when we can live almost a normal life.\u201d", "She equates using the calculator daily to checking the weather, which is the exact attitude scientists want people to adopt, said Kaitlyn Johnson, who helped create a holiday risk estimator as part of her work with the Rockefeller Foundation\u2019s Pandemic Prevention Institute. \u201cIn the same way we use weather apps to understand where there is a risk of a hurricane, we want people to be able to monitor their risk of being exposed to a disease,\u201d she said.", "Her colleague, Sam Scarpino, who also works at the institute, said he hopes people adopt these calculators to assess all types of health risks \u2014 maybe the flu is prevalent or there is a measles outbreak \u2014 in the future. \u201cWhether someone is a public health official taking care of their community or someone going on a date, people need tools to translate all this complexity into a decision,\u201d he said. \u201cI think the public is learning to adopt these kinds of tools to make decisions in a little more informed way.\u201d", "Some users, however, report feeling more anxious after using them. Nick Rafter, 38, a real estate agent in the Ozone Park section of Queens, was running the numbers before social gatherings or trips away. \u201cIt was mostly out of curiosity, not to decide whether or not to do them,\u201d he said. \u201cI wanted to be prepared for what could happen, so I planned ahead. If I got Covid, I could at least say, \u2018Well the calculator did say my chances were. \u2026\u201d", "But he soon realized that knowing his risk made his emotional state more volatile. \u201cI started thinking, \u2018Maybe I shouldn\u2019t have come? Am I getting infected now?\u2019 and I would have a miserable time and feel anxious,\u201d he said. After he got his booster shot in November, he decided to stop running the numbers, especially if he was going to gatherings anyway. (He did say he may turn back to a calculator in the future. \u201cI\u2019m going on a cruise in February,\u201d he said. \u201cI might see myself using it for that.\u201d)", "Some are discovering, thanks to the calculators, that the people around them may not be the best judge of risk. Ms. Bergstom was asked out on a date recently by a scientist who claimed to be cautious and safe. But after he suggested a date, she realized he wasn\u2019t. ", "\u201cHe told me where he wanted to go, and I looked online, and I ran the numbers, and it\u2019s all indoors and very small, and the day and time he invited me out was going to be the most crowded,\u201d she said. \u201cI didn\u2019t even want to suggest something else. I turned him down because I thought his decision making was poor.\u201d", "Other people like calculators because they give them neutral, nonemotional data on which to make their decisions (and back them up).", "\u201cIt\u2019s like having a mediator come in and say, \u2018This isn\u2019t a good idea,\u2019\u201d Mr. Lee said. \u201cIf your parents want to gather and you don\u2019t, this takes away the emotions of it. It\u2019s just medical advice saying, \u2018This is not a good idea.\u2019\u201d Ms. Johnson has had multiple friends reach out to her and say they are using it to explain to their families the risk of gatherings.", "Of course, some people looking for a way out of a social function don\u2019t always get the results they are looking for.", "\u201cSome of the comments we get our hilarious,\u201d said Dr. Sinha, one of the creators of the calculator in Canada. \u201cI had one person saying before the U.S. Thanksgiving that he didn\u2019t want to visit his in-laws, and he was hoping the risk calculator would say it was a high-risk event. Unfortunately it was low.\u201d"]
